column2: PARAMETERS
column3: Symbol parameters description in expression view & customizer GUI
column4: IndSense alternative description

column2:
The expression defining whether or not the ADC 
functionality should be present in the component. For 
CapSense component, it is always false. For ADC 
component, it is always true. For CapSense_ADC 
component, it is true if the total count of required 
ADC channels (AdcTotalChannels parameter) is greater 
than 0, and false otherwise.

Enable the ADC channel that does not require a 
dedicated port pin input.  When disabled, all ADC input 
channels have port pins assigned.  When enabled, the 
ADC channel selected by the AdcSelectAmuxBusChannel 
parameter does not use a dedicated pin for input, 
instead it takes an input from AMUXBUS-B.

Enables the auto-zero time period for AZ prior to fine 
initialization in ADC conversion.

Sets an auto-zero time period for AZ prior to fine 
initialization in ADC converson (in cycles). 
Applicable only if AdcAzEnable parameter is enabled. 
The range of valid values is 1-255.

Contains a comma-separated list of pin aliases for ADC 
input channels.  Used by the AdcInput pins on the 
component schematic.
ADC resolution selection.

Selects the ADC channel that does not require a 
dedicated port pin input. The range of valid values is 
from 0 to $AdcTotalChannels-1.

The total input channels to ADC. The range of valid 
values is from 1 (10-bit ADC component) or 0 (CapSense_ADC 
component) to 10. The ADC functionality of CapSense_ADC 
component is disabled when a parameter value is set to 
0.

The expression providing the total count of dedicated 
ADC channels. When AdcAmuxbInputEnable is set to false, 
the parameter value equals AdcTotalChannels, otherwise, 
it is decremented by one.

The reference voltage used for ADC operation, in Volts. 
The range of valid values is from 1.2V to VDDA - 0.6V, 
where VDDA is the input voltage of VDDA pin as set in 
the Design-Wide Resources (*.cydwr) System editor. 
When set to -1 (default), the reference voltage (VREF) 
depends on VDDA:  VDDA < 2.733V: VREF = 1.2V  2.733V <= 
VDDA < 4.5V: VREF = 2.133V  VDDA >= 4.5V: VREF = 3.84V 
The macro generated by the API customizer reflects 
VREFGEN gain register value.

Selects the type of baseline needed for design.  IIR 
(default) - Selects the IIR filter based baseline 
algorithm.  CY (Bucket) Baseline - Selects Cypress' 
"bucket" method for the baseline algorithm.

Enable the turning-off block after a scan to save 
additional power.  Disabled (default) - The SENSE_HW block 
will be always turned ON.   This allows the other 
components (IDAC) work along with component in 
a project.  Enabled - The SENSE_HW block will be turned ON 
only during a scan.

Selects the IDAC gain setting for CSD sensing on CSD 
block 0.  Applicable only for CSDv1 IP.

Selects the IDAC gain setting for CSD sensing on CSD 
block 0.  Applicable only for CSDv2 IP.

Contains a comma-separated list of the electrode 
aliases for CSD widgets on CSD block 0.  Used by the 
Sns/Sns0 pins on the component schematic.

Contains the total count of the CSD electrodes on CSD 
block 0.  Used by the Sns/Sns0 pins on the component 
schematic.

Configures a delay between the sensor signal and shield 
electrode signal for phase alignment.  Most designs 
work with the No Delay option, and it is the 
recommended value.  Applicable only if the shield 
electrode is enabled.  Applicable to the first CSD 
block if CSD2x is enabled.

Configures a delay between the sensor signal and shield 
electrode signal for phase alignment.  Most designs 
work with the No Delay option, and it is the 
recommended value.  Applicable only if the shield 
electrode is enabled.  Applicable to the first CSD 
block if CSD2x is enabled.

A shield electrode is used to reduce the sensor 
parasitic capacitance, enable water-tolerant   CapSense 
designs, and enhance the detection range for Proximity 
sensors.  When the shield electrode is disabled, all 
configurable parameters associated with the shield 
electrode are hidden.  Applicable to the first CSD 
block if CSD2x is enabled.

Selects the initialization source for the shield tank 
electrode, when the shield tank (Csh) capacitor is 
enabled.  Two options are available:  - Vref - 
precharge the shield tank by connecting Vref to the Csh 
capacitor.  - IO Buffer - precharge shield tank by 
connecting the VDD supply to the Csh capacitor and 
turning it off   using feedback system when the Csh 
voltage reaches Vref.  This option is available only 
when the Csh capacitor is assigned to one of the 
dedicated Csh pins   (refer to device datasheet for pin 
details) and these dedicated pins are available for Csh 
when the CSX sensing method is not used in the project. 
The recommended source of precharge is IO buffer. 
Applicable only if the shield electrode is enabled. 
Applicable to the first CSD block if CSD2x is enabled.

A shield tank capacitor is used to increase the drive 
capacity of the shield electrode driver and recommended 
for enabling when the shield electrode capacitance is 
higher than 100 pF.  The recommended value for a shield 
tank capacitor is 10 nF/5v/X7R or an NPO capacitor. 
Applicable only if the shield electrode is enabled. 
Applicable to the first CSD block if CSD2x is enabled.

Select the number of shield electrodes required in the 
design.   Most designs work with one dedicated shield 
electrode; however, some designs require multiple 
dedicated shield electrodes to ease the PCB layout 
routing or to minimize the PCB real-estate used for the 
shield layer.  The minimum value is 0 (i.e. shield 
signal could be routed to sensors using Inactive sensor 
connection parameter) and the maximum value is equal to 
the total number of CapSense-enabled port pins 
available for the selected device.  Applicable only if 
the shield electrode is enabled.  Applicable to the 
first CSD block if CSD2x is enabled.

Selects the IDAC gain setting for CSD sensing on CSD 
block 1.  Applicable only for CSDv1 IP.  Applicable 
only if CSD2x is enabled.

Selects the IDAC gain setting for CSD sensing on CSD 
block 1.  Applicable only for CSDv2 IP.  Applicable 
only if CSD2x is enabled.

Contains a comma-separated list of electrode aliases 
for the CSD widgets on CSD block 1.  Used by the Sns1 
pin on the component schematic.  Applicable only if 
CSD2x is enabled.

Contains the total count of the CSD electrodes on CSD 
block 1.  Used by the Sns1 pin on the component 
schematic.  Applicable only if CSD2x is enabled.

Configures a delay between the sensor signal and shield 
electrode signal for phase alignment.  Most designs 
work with the No Delay option, and it is the 
recommended value.  Applicable only if the shield 
electrode is enabled.  Applicable to the second CSD 
block if CSD2x is enabled.

Configures a delay between the sensor signal and shield 
electrode signal for the phase alignment.  Most designs 
work with the No Delay option, and it is the 
recommended value.  Applicable only if the shield 
electrode is enabled.  Applicable to the second CSD 
block if CSD2x is enabled.

A shield electrode is used to reduce the sensor 
parasitic capacitance, enable water-tolerant CapSense 
designs and enhance the detection range for Proximity 
sensors.  Applicable to the second CSD block if CSD2x 
is enabled.

Selects the initialization source for the shield tank 
electrode, when the shield tank (Csh) capacitor is 
enabled.  Two options are available:  - Vref - 
precharge the shield tank by connecting Vref to the Csh 
capacitor.  - IO Buffer - precharge the shield tank by 
connecting the VDD supply to the Csh capacitor and 
turning it off using the feedback system when the Csh 
voltage reaches Vref.  This option is available only 
when the Csh capacitor is assigned to one of the 
dedicated Csh pins   (refer to device datasheet for pin 
details) and these dedicated pins are available for Csh 
when the CSX sensing method is not used in the project. 
The recommended source of precharge is IO buffer. 
Applicable only if the shield electrode is enabled. 
Applicable to the second CSD block if CSD2x is enabled.

A shield tank capacitor is used to increase the drive 
capacity of the shield electrode driver and is 
recommended to enable when the shield electrode 
capacitance is higher than 100pF.  The recommended 
value for a shield tank capacitor is 10 nF/5v/X7R or an 
NPO capacitor.  Applicable only if the shield electrode 
is enabled.  Applicable to the second CSD block if 
CSD2x is enabled.

Selects the number of shield electrodes required in the 
design.   Most designs work with one dedicated shield 
electrode; however, some designs require multiple 
dedicated shield electrodes to ease the PCB layout 
routing or to minimize the PCB real-estate used for the 
shield layer.  The minimum value is 0 (i.e. shield 
signal could be routed to sensors using Inactive sensor 
connection parameter) and the maximum value is equal to 
the total number of CapSense-enabled port pins 
available for the selected device.  Applicable only if 
the shield electrode is enabled.  Applicable to the 
second CSD block if CSD2x is enabled.

Enabling this parameter allows two sensors to be 
scanned in two, simultaneously used, CSD hardware 
blocks.  This option is available only on devices 
supporting two CSD blocks.

Enables auto-zero prior to fine initialization for the 
CSD sensing method.  Applicable only for CSDv2 IP.

Sets an auto-zero time period for AZ prior to fine 
initialization for the CSD sensing method.  Applicable 
only for CSDv2 IP.  Applicable only when 
CsdAutoZeroEnable is enabled.

When selected, all CSD widgets share the same sense 
clock with the frequency specified in   the Sense clock 
frequency (kHz) parameter.  Otherwise, a sense clock 
frequency can be entered   separately for each CSD 
widget in the Widget Details tab.

Selects the compensation IDAC implementation method 
when using CSDv2.  Enabled (default) - Use IDACB as the 
compensation IDAC  Disabled - Use LEG2 of IDACA as 
compensation IDAC  Applicable only for CSDv2 IP.

Represents the percentage of contribution by the 
compensation IDAC when using the Dual IDAC sensing.

The internal parameter automatically enabled by the 
customizer when at least one widget uses the CSD 
sensing mode AND the dual-channel CSD (CSD2x) is not 
selected.

When enabled, the values of IDACs of CSD widgets are 
automatically set by the component.  It is recommended 
to select Enable IDAC auto-calibration for robust 
operation.  SmartSense Auto-tuning can be enabled only 
when Enable IDAC auto-calibration is selected.

The compensation IDAC is used to compensate for the 
sensor parasitic capacitance to improve the 
performance.  Enabling the compensation IDAC is 
recommended unless one IDAC is required for other 
purpose use in the project.

Selects the sensing Config needed in CSD mode.  IDAC 
Sourcing (default) - Select IDAC sourcing sensing 
configuration (-ve charge transfer)  IDAC Sinking - 
Select the IDAC sinking sensing configuration (+ve 
charge transfer).

Selects the state of the sensor when not being scanned. 
- Ground (default) - All inactive sensors are connected 
to Ground.  - High-Z - All inactive sensors are 
floating (not connected to GND or Shield).  - Shield - 
All inactive sensors are connected to Shield.  The 
Shield option is available only if an Enable shield 
electrode check-box is set.  Ground is the recommended 
option for this parameter when the water tolerance is 
not required for the design.  Selects Shield when the 
design needs water tolerance or sensor parasitic 
capacitance reduction in a design.

Selects resistance of the switches used for Cmod and 
Csh_Tank initialization.  Applicable only for CSDv2 IP.

Selects the modulator clock frequency used for the CSD 
sensing method.  Enters any value between the min and 
max limits, based on the availability of the clock 
divider.  The higher modulator clock frequency reduces 
sensor scan time.  Therefore, results in lower power 
and reduces the noise in the raw counts,   so 
recommended to use the highest possible frequency.

Enables noise metric evaluation for CSD scan. 
Applicable only for CSDv2 IP.

Sets the max allowed bad conversions in a sample. 
Applicable only for CSDv2 IP.  Applicable only if 
CsdNoiseMetricEnable is enabled.

Represents the settling time delay (in uS) prior to 
scan is started.

Represents the rawcount calibration level (percentage) 
to be used when auto-calibration of CSD widgets is 
enabled.

Sets the CSD sense clock frequency.  When SmartSense is 
selected in the CSD tuning mode, sense clock frequency 
is automatically   set by the component to the optimal 
value.  When the Enable common sense clock is 
unselected, a sense clock frequency can be set 
individually for each widget in the Widget Details tab.

The sense clock is used to sample the input sensor. 
The Spread Spectrum Clock (SSC) provides a dithering 
clock source with a center frequency equal to the 
frequency set in the sense clock frequency parameter. 
The PRS clock source spreads the clock using pseudo- 
random sequencer.  Direct source disables both SSC and 
PRS sources and uses a fixed-frequency clock.

Selects the resistance of switches used to drive the 
shield electrode when an internal shield drive is used.

Represents a series resistance value to be considered 
while decising on the widget/sensor clock value when 
auto-tuning is enabled.

Select the tuning mode for CSD widgets. Three options 
are available:  SmartSense (Full Auto-Tune) - This is 
the quickest way to tune a design. Mostly all widget 
parameters are automatically tuned by the component. 
SmartSense (Hardware parameters only) - Hardware 
parameters are automatically set by the component, all 
threshold parameters can be manually set by the user 
Manual - SmartSense auto-tuning is disabled, all widget 
parameters must be manually tuned.  This setting is 
applicable only to CSD widgets (CSX widgets always use 
Manual tuning).

The reference voltage used for CSDv2 operation, in 
Volts. The range of valid values is from 1.2V to VDDA - 
0.6V, where VDDA is the input voltage of the VDDA pin 
as set in the Design-Wide Resources (*.cydwr) System 
editor.  When set to -1 (default), the reference 
voltage value (VREF) depends on VDDA:  VDDA < 2.6V: 
VREF = 1.2V  2.6V <= VDDA < 3.2V: VREF = 1.4769V  3.2V 
<= VDDA < 4.7V: VREF = 2.0211V  VDDA >= 4.7V: VREF = 
2.7429V  The macro generated by the API customizer 
reflects the VREFGEN gain register value.  Applicable 
only for CSDv2 IP.

Selects the IDAC gain setting for CSX sensing on CSD 
block 0.  Applicable only for CSDv1 IP.

Selects the IDAC gain setting for CSX sensing on CSD 
block 0.  Applicable only for CSDv2 IP.

Contains a comma-separated list of the Rx sensor 
aliases for CSX sensors on CSD block 0.  Used by the 
Rx0 pin on the component schematic.  Applicable only if 
CSX2x is enabled.

Contains the total count of the Rx electrodes on CSD 
block 0.  Used by the Rx0 pin on the component 
schematic.  Applicable only if CSX2x is enabled.

Selects the IDAC gain setting for CSX sensing on CSD 
block 1.  Applicable only for CSDv1 IP.  Applicable 
only if CSX2x is enabled.

Selects the IDAC gain setting for CSX sensing on CSD 
block 1.  Applicable only for CSDv2 IP.  Applicable 
only if CSX2x is enabled.

Contains a comma-separated list of the Rx electrode 
aliases for the CSX sensors on CSD block 1.  Used by 
the Rx1 pin on the component schematic.  Applicable 
only if CSX2x is enabled.

Contains the total count of the Rx electrodes on CSD 
block 1.  Used by the Rx1 pin on the component 
schematic.  Applicable only if CSX2x is enabled.

Indicates whether the two-channel operation of CSX 
widgets (CSX2x) is enabled.

Enables auto-zero prior to fine initialization for the 
CSX sensing method.

Sets an auto-zero time period for AZ prior to fine 
initialization in the CSX sensing method.

When selected, all CSX widgets share the same Tx clock 
with the frequency specified in the   Tx clock 
frequency (kHz) parameter.  Otherwise, a Tx clock 
frequency can be entered separately   for each CSX 
widget in the Widget Details tab.

The internal parameter automatically enabled by the 
customizer when at least one widget uses the CSX 
sensing mode AND dual-channel CSX (CSX2x) is not 
selected.

When enabled, IDACs values for the CSX widgets are 
automatically set by the component.  It is recommended 
to select Enable IDAC auto-calibration for robust 
operation.

Controls how many of the IDAC bits should be considered 
for auto-calibration of the CSX widgets.  Less bits 
leads to faster calibration time.  Applicable only for 
CSDv1 IP.

Controls how many of the IDAC bits should be considered 
for auto-calibration of the CSX widgets.  Less bits 
leads to faster calibration time.  Applicable only for 
CSDv2 IP.

Selects the resistance of switches used for Cint1 and 
Cint2 initialization.

Indicates the maximum number of reported fingers. If 
the number of fingers on the touchpad exceeds this 
number, no finger will be reported.

The maximum possible number of local maxima for CSX 
touchpad.

Selects the modulator clock frequency used for the CSX 
sensing method.  Enter any value between the min and 
max limits based on the availability of the clock 
divider.
Enable/disable the multi-phase scan for CSX.
Enables the noise metric evaluation for the CSX scan.

Sets max allowed bad conversions in a sample. 
Applicable only for CSDv2 IP.  Applicable only if 
CsxNoiseMetricEnable is enabled.

Contains a comma-separated list of the Multiphase Tx 
electrode aliases for the CSX sensors.  Used by the 
Mptx/Mptx2x pins on the component schematic. 
Applicable only if Multiphase Tx is enabled for at 
least one widget.

Contains a comma-separated list of the Rx electrode 
aliases for the CSX widgets.  Used by the Rx pin on the 
component schematic.  Applicable only if CSX2x is 
disabled.

Contains a comma-separated list of the Tx electrode 
aliases for the CSX widgets.  Used by the Tx/Tx2x pins 
on the component schematic.

Contains the total count of the Multiphase Tx 
electrodes for the CSX widgets.  Used by the 
Mptx/Mptx2x pins on the component schematic. 
Applicable only if the Multiphase Tx is enabled for at 
least one widget.

Contains the total count of the Rx electrodes for the 
CSX widgets.  Used by the Rx pin on the component 
schematic.  Applicable only if CSX2x is disabled.

Contains the total count of the Rx electrodes for the 
CSX widgets.  Used by the Tx/Tx2x pin on the component 
schematic.

Represents the rawcount calibration level (percentage) 
to be used when auto-calibration of the CSX widgets is 
enabled.

Enable/Disable over sampling and scan skip on specific 
nodes.

Sets the CSX Tx clock frequency.  The highest Tx clock 
frequency producing the maximum signal and is the 
recommended setting.  When the Enable common Tx clock 
is unselected, a Tx Clock frequency can be set 
individually   for each widget in the Widget Details 
tab.

A Tx clock is used to sample the input sensor.  The 
Spread Spectrum Clock (SSC) provides a dithering clock 
source with the center frequency equal to the frequency 
set in the Tx Clock frequency parameter.  Direct source 
disables the SSC source and uses a fixed-frequency 
clock.  Auto is the recommended clock source selection.

Enables auto-zero prior to fine initialization for the 
ISX sensing method.

Sets an auto-zero time period for AZ prior to fine 
initialization in the ISX sensing method.

The internal parameter automatically enabled by the 
customizer when at least one widget uses the ISX 
sensing mode.

When enabled, IDACs values and best resonant frequency 
within 10% of target frequency for the ISX widgets are 
automatically set by the component.  It is recommended 
to select Enable auto-calibration for robust operation.

Controls how many of the IDAC bits should be considered 
for auto-calibration of the ISX widgets.  Fewer bits 
leads to faster calibration time.

Selects the resistance of switches used for Cint1 and 
Cint2 initialization.

Selects the modulator clock frequency used for the ISX 
sensing method.  Enter any value between the min and 
max limits based on the availability of the clock 
divider.
Enables the noise metric evaluation for the ISX scan.

Sets max allowed bad conversions in a sample. 
Applicable only if IsxNoiseMetricEnable is enabled.

Contains a comma-separated list of the Rx electrode 
aliases for the ISX widgets.  Used by the Rx pin on the 
component schematic.

Contains a comma-separated list of the Ix electrode 
aliases for the ISX widgets.  Used by the Ix  pins on the 
component schematic.

Contains the total count of the Rx electrodes for the 
ISX widgets.  Used by the Rx pin on the component 
schematic.

Contains the total count of the Ix electrodes for the 
ISX widgets.  Used by the Ix pin on the component 
schematic.

Represents the rawcount calibration level (percentage) 
to be used when auto-calibration of the ISX widgets is 
enabled.

Enable/Disable over sampling and scan skip on specific 
nodes.

The internal parameter enabling generation of a special 
set of component APIs to be processed by the Doxygen 
tool.  The configuration consistency is not guaranteed, 
cannot be used on the real designs.

Internal read-only parameter set to true on ADC and 
CapSense_ADC component catalog placements.
column4:
Internal read-only parameter set to true on ADC and 
CapSense_ADC component catalog placements.

column2:
The internal read-only parameter set to true on 
CapSense and CapSense_ADC component catalog placements.
column4:
The internal read-only parameter set to true on 
CapSense and CapSense_ADC component catalog placements.

column2: Represents a low baseline reset size for sensors.
Indicates whether multi-frequency scanning is enabled.

Selects a number of centroid supported on sliders. The 
available options are 1, 2 or 3. The default is 1 
(Legacy).  Applicable only to Radial and Linear slider 
widgets. Not supported on diplexed sliders.

Indicates whether the debounce for ON to OFF transition 
is enabled.

The centroid Position IIR filter coefficient for 
sliders and touchpads. The range of valid values is 
1-255.

The finite impulse response filter (no feedback) with 
equally weighted coefficients.  It takes the most 
recent samples and computes their average.  Eliminates 
the periodic noise (e.g. noise from AC remains). 
Applicable only to proximity widgets.

The raw count averege filter sample size selection. 
Applicable only to proximity widgets when the average 
filter is enabled.

Enables the custom filter.  Applicable only to 
proximity widgets.

Baseline IIR filter coefficient selection for sensors 
in proximity widgets.  The range of valid values is 
1-255.
Applicable only to proximity widgets.

Enables the infinite-impulse response filter with a 
step response similar to an RC low-pass filter  thereby 
passing the low frequency signals (finger touch 
responses).  Applicable only to proximity widgets.

the coefficient (N) of an IIR filter for raw counts. 
The range of valid values is 1-128.  Applicable only to 
proximity widgets when the IIR filter is enabled.

Applicable only to proximity widgets when IIR filter is 
enabled.

Enables a non-linear filter that takes three of most 
recent samples and computes the median value.  This 
filter eliminates spikes noise typically caused by 
motors and switching power supplies.  Applicable only 
to proximity widgets.

The finite-impulse response filter (no feedback) with 
equally weighted coefficients.  It takes four of most 
recent samples and computes their average.  Eliminates 
the periodic noise (e.g. noise from AC remains). 
Applicable only to regular (non-proximity) widgets.

The raw count average filter sample size selection. 
Applicable only to regular (non-proximity) widgets when 
the average filter is enabled.

Enables the custom filter.  Applicable only to regular 
(non-proximity) widgets.

Baseline IIR filter coefficient selection for sensors 
in non-proximity widgets.  The range of valid values is 
1-255.

Enables the infinite-impulse response filter with a 
step response similar to an RC low-pass filter  thereby 
passing low frequency signals (finger touch responses). 
Applicable only to regular (non-proximity) widgets.

The IIR filter coefficient (N) for raw counts.   The 
range of valid values in 1-128.  Applicable only to 
regular (non-proximity) widgets when the IIR filter is 
enabled.

Enables a non-linear filter that takes three of most 
recent samples and computes the median value.  This 
filter eliminates spikes noise typically caused by 
motors and switching power supplies.  Applicable only 
to regular (non-proximity) widgets.

The BIST/Class-B library supports the following: the 
sensor short test, test baseline and raw count limits, 
CRC for widget-specific register map data, measuring an 
external cap (Cmod, Csh_tank, CintA and CintB) value 
and test baseline data consistency.  Additionally, 
measuring of VDDA and two internal reference caps are 
supported for CSDv2.
column4:
The BIST/Class-B library supports the following: the 
sensor short test, test baseline and raw count limits, 
CRC for widget-specific register map data, measuring an 
external cap (Cmod, Csh_tank, CintA and CintB) value 
and test baseline data consistency.  Additionally, 
measuring of VDDA and two internal reference caps are 
supported for CSDv2.

column2:
When enabled, the baseline is always updated and when 
disabled, the baseline is updated only when the 
difference between the baseline and raw count is less 
than the noise threshold.  The sensor auto-reset 
prevents the sensor from permanently turning on when 
the raw count  accidentally rises because of a large 
power-supply  voltage fluctuation or due to other 
spurious conditions.

Selection of the sensor auto-reset implementation 
method.

The number of samples required before a baseline is 
reset, when the sensor auto-reset is enabled.

Selects a data size for widgets in the component.  This 
applies to Finger Threshold (all widgets) and Proximity 
Touch Threshold (proximity widgets).  In SmartSense 
(Full Auto-tune) mode, parameter value is ignored and 
threshold register size is always 16-bit.

The expression provided by the customizer to obtain a 
VDDA value as set in the System DWR.
Contains the widget/sensor configuration.
PROPERTIES
Finger capacitance for the widget, in pF.

Enables usage of specific duplexing sensor pattern to 
double the slider physical touch sensing area.
Sets the maximum Centroid position for the slider.

Sets the maximum column (X-axis) Centroid position fo a 
touchpad.

Sets the maximum row (Y-axis) Centroid position for 
touchpad.

Enables the specific filter on a Centroid position 
value reducing noise due to a varying finger touch.
Enables Multiphase Tx scan of the CSX widget.
Sets the sense clock frequency for the CSD widget.

Displays the actual sense clock frequency (as obtained 
with the closest valid sense clock divider).

Sets the row sense clock frequency for the CSD matrix 
buttons and Touchpad widgets.

Displays the actual row sense clock frequency (as 
obtained with the closest valid row sense clock 
divider).
Sets the Tx clock frequency for the CSX widget.

Displays the actual Tx clock frequency (as obtained 
with the closest valid Tx clock divider).
Sets the Ix clock frequency for the ISX widget.

Displays the actual Ix clock frequency (as obtained 
with the closest valid Ix clock divider).

Selects the scan resolution of CSD widgets (resolution 
of capacitance-to-digital conversion).
Selects the number of sub-conversions for this widget.
Sets the modulator IDAC value for the widgets.

Sets a modulator IDAC value for the row sensors of the 
CSD Matrix Buttons and Touchpad widgets.

Sets the touch level to determine the sensor state 
based on the signal.

Sets the touch level to detect a finger touch on the 
proximity sensor.

Sets the raw count limit below which is considered as 
noise.

Sets the raw count limit below which the baseline is 
not updated for the number of samples specified by the 
Low baseline reset parameter.

Sets the number of abnormally low raw counts required 
to reset the baseline.

A parameter used to prevent the sensor status output 
from random toggling due to system noise, used in 
conjunction with the Thresholds (Finger or Proximity/Touch) 
to determine the sensor state.

Sets the number of consecutive Component scans during 
which a sensor must be active to generate an ON state.

Sets the number of consecutive Component scans during 
which a sensor must be inctive to generate an OFF state.

The square of the "speed" (maximum distance change per 
refresh interval) threshold distinguishing a fast 
finger movement from separate finger touches (in 
[pixels/refresh interval]).  Squared speeds exceeding 
this value indicate separate finger touches.  Squared 
speeds below this value indicate fast single finger 
movement.

Sets the Compensation IDAC value for the specific CSD 
sensor.
Sets an IDAC value for each sensor/node.

Selects a port pin for the sensor (CSD sensing) and 
electrode (CSX sensing). The available options are to 
use a dedicated pin for a sensor or reuse one or more 
pins from any other sensors in the component. Reusing 
the pins of any other sensors from any widgets helps to 
create a ganged sensor.
IDAC value of the sensor
HELP

Opens (load) a previously saved configuration (XML)
file for CapSense component.
column4:
Opens (load) a previously saved configuration (XML)
file for the Component.

column2: Saves the current component configuration into a (XML) file.

The CapSense component firmware library uses the
data structure (known as Register map) to store the
configurable parameters, various outputs and signal
 of the component. The Export Register Map button
creates an explanation for registers and bit fields in
the register map in PDF or XML file which can be used
as reference for development.
column4:
The Component firmware library uses the data 
structure (known as Register map) to store the
configurable parameters, various outputs and signal
 of the Component. The Export Register Map button
creates an explanation for registers and bit fields in
the register map in PDF or XML file which can be used
as reference for development.

column2: Exports the current component register map to the XML format.
Exports the current component register map to the PDF format.
Moves the selected widget up by one on the list.
Moves the selected widget down by one on the list.
Deletes the selected widget from the list.

Shows an icon to indicate the widget type. 
Not configurable (i.e. widget type cannot be changed
once selected initially).

The editable field to enter a widget name. 
The max of 16 aplha-numeric characters only, the
first character should be a letter. Widget names
must be unique (case-insensitive).

The drop-down to select the sensing mode for each
widget: 
The CSD sensing method (Capacitive Sigma Delta) is
Cypress patented method of performing self-capacitance
measurements. All widget types support the CSD sensing. 
The CSX sensing method is Cypress patented method of
performing mutual-capacitance measurements. Only
buttons, matrix buttons, and touchpad widgets support
the CSX sensing. 
The ISX sensing method is the method of performing
inductive sensing. Only proximity sensor widgets
support ISX sensing.
column4:
The drop-down to select the sensing mode for each
widget: 
The ISX sensing method is the method of performing
inductive sensing. Only proximity sensor widgets
support ISX sensing.

column2:
The sensing element refers to terminals of the
component assigned to port pins to connect to
physical sensors on the user interface panel. 

The following element numbers are supported by the
CSD sensing method: 
Button supports 1 to 32 sensors within a widget. 
Linear Slider supports 3 to 32 segments within a widget. 
Radial Slider supports 3 to 32 segments within a widget. 
Matrix Buttons support 2 to 16 rows and columns. The
total intersections number (sensors) are equal to
rows X columns, limited to maximum of 32. 
Touchpad supports 3 to 16 rows and columns 
Proximity supports 1  to 16   sensors within a widget. 

The following element numbers are supported by
the CSX sensing method: 
Button - 1 to 32 Rx electrodes (for 1 to 32 sensors)
and Tx is fixed to 1. 
Matrix Buttons - 2 to 16 Tx and Rx. The total
intersections number (node) is equal to Tx X Rx
limited to maximum of 32. 

The following element numbers are supported by
the ISX sensing method:
Proximity supports 1 senser per widget.
column4:
The sensing element refers to terminals of the
Component assigned to port pins to connect to
physical sensors on the user interface panel. 

The following element numbers are supported by
the ISX sensing method:
Proximity supports 1 senser per widget.

column2:
Indicates the total number of electrodes (port pins)
used by the CSD widgets, including Cmod, Csh and
Shield electrodes.

Indicates the total number of electrodes (port pins)
used by the CSX widgets, including the CintA and
CintB capacitors.

Indicates the total number of electrodes (port pins)
used by the ISX widgets, including the CintA and
CintB capacitors.

Indicates the total number of port pins required for
the design. This does not include port pins used by
other components in the project. The number of
pins required should always be less than or equal
to the number of pins available for the project to
build it successfully.

Indicates the total number of port pins available for
the selected device.

Displays the closest valid value of the modulator
clock frequency based on the calculated modulator
clock divider (HFCLK/MODCLK ratio).

Displays the closest valid value of the modulator
clock frequency based on the calculated modulator
clock divider (HFCLK/MODCLK ratio).
REGFLASH
Array of flash widget objects
Structure with all Ganged Flash electrode objects

Points to the array of the FLASH Sensor Objects or FLASH IO Objects that belong to this widget. 
Sensing block uses this pointer to access and configure IOs for the scanning. 
Bit #2 in WD_STATIC_CONFIG field indicates the type of array:  
1 - Sensor Object;  
0 - IO Object.

Points to the Widget Object in RAM. Sensing block uses it to access scan parameters. 
Processing uses it to access threshold and widget specific data.

Points to the array of Sensor Objects in RAM. 
The sensing and processing blocks use it to access the scan data.
Points to the array of the Filter History Objects in RAM that belongs to this widget.

Points to the array of the debounce counters. 
The size of the debounce counter is 8 bits. 
These arrays are not part of the data structure.
Miscellaneous configuration flags.
The sense/Tx frequency selection: 0 - Common, 1 - Individual (per widget).
Duplexing Enable/Disable for linear sliders.
The widget contains a sensor ganged to other sensors.
Some pin from this widget is used by other sensors to make a ganged sensor.

The centroid position median filter Enable/Disable.
The centroid position average filter Enable/Disable.
The centroid position jitter filter Enable/Disable.
The multiphase Tx scan Enable (CSX widgets only).

The square of the "speed" (maximum distance change per refresh interval) threshold 
distinguishing a fast finger movement from separate finger touches (in [pixels/refresh interval]). 
Squared speeds exceeding this value indicate separate finger touches. 
Squared speeds below this value indicate fast single finger movement.
